text: Winter Camp 2012 Sequences Alexander Remorov Sequences Alexander Remorov alexanderrem@gmail.com Warm-up Problem 1: Given a positive integer n, consider a sequence of real numbers a0, a1, . . . , an deﬁned as a0 = 1 2 and ak = ak−1 + a2 k−1 n for 1 ≤ k ≤ n. Prove that 1 − 1 n < an < 1. Solution: The expression ak = ak−1 + a2 k−1 n (1) seems rather hard to work with so let us think about how we can rewrite it. If we multiply both sides by n and factor out ak−1 on the right side, we get: nak = ak−1(n + ak−1) ⇔ ak ak−1 = n + ak−1 n (2) and if we divide (1) by akak−1, we get: 1 ak−1 = 1 ak + ak−1 ak · 1 n (3) Substituting (2) into (3) and rearranging, we have: 1 ak−1 − 1 ak = 1 n + ak (4) which is much simpler. If we add (4) for k = 1, 2, . . . , n we get: 1 a0 − 1 an = n∑ k=1 1 n + ak ⇔ 1 an = 2 − n∑ k=1 1 n + ak (5) Thus now it suﬃces to show n−2 n−1 < ∑n k=1 1 n+ak < 1. The second inequality is easy - using (1) and a0 > 0 we have 0 < a0 < a1 < . . . < an, so n + ak > n for 1 ≤ k ≤ n. To prove the ﬁrst inequality we note that since an < 1, it follows that ak < 1 for 1 ≤ k ≤ n and thus 1 n+ak > 1 n+1 , so ∑n k=1 1 n+ak > n n+1 > n−2 n−1 and we are done. Comment: Let us try to explain some motivation for (4). Using just (1) and the fact that a0 = 0, it is diﬃcult to get much further than 0 < a0 < a1 < . . . < an - because of the order 2 terms a2 k n present, and it is not clear how to get a bound on them. How can we get rid of the order 2 terms? Divide both sides by akak−1 to get (3). We now have an expression for 1 ak−1 − 1 ak (which gives a telescoping sum), and it is equal to ak−1 ak · 1 n . While this is enough to give us an < 1 (check this yourself), we realize that more is needed to prove an > 1 − 1 n . At this point we make use of (1) again to get (2), and then (4). 1 Winter Camp 2012 Sequences Alexander Remorov Warm-up Problem 2: The sequence {an}∞ n=1 satisﬁes a1 = 1 and for n ≥ 1, a2n = an + 1; a2n+1 = 1 a2n Prove that every positive rational number occurs in the sequence exactly once. Solution: Let us start by writing out the ﬁrst few terms in the sequence. They are 1, 2, 1 2 , 3 2 , 2 3 , 5 3 , 3 5 . We notice that starting from the second term, the even-numbered terms are greater than 1, while the odd-numbered ones are less than 1. Proving this rigorously is straightforward with induction. Now, every positive rational number can be written as a b where a, b are positive integers with gcd(a, b) = 1. We will use double induction on a, b. The base case is a = b = 1 and is clear since a1 = 1. Assume now for positive integers a, b, satisfying gcd(a, b), we want to show a b ∈ {an}∞ n=1 and we know c d ∈ {an}∞ n=1 for all positive integers c, d satisfying c ≤ a − 1, d ≤ b or c ≤ a, d ≤ b − 1. We can assume a ̸= b (or else a = b = 1 and this case is already done.) If a > b, then a b > 1, so by our ﬁrst observation, we want to prove that a b = a2n for some n. But a2n = an + 1, so we want to prove an = a−b b for some n - which we know is true by the induction assumption. If b > a, then a b < 1, so by our ﬁrst observation, we want to prove a b = a2n+1 for some n. But a2n+1 = 1 a2n so we want to prove b a = a2n for some n - which we already know how to do - since an = b−a a for some n by the induction assumption. The induction step is complete, so every positive rational number occurs in the sequence at least once. Finally, we need to prove that no two terms in the sequence are the same. Assume we have am = an for some m ̸= n and m + n minimal. It is clear that m ̸= 1 and n ̸= 1 (as ak ̸= 1 for k > 1). Then by our ﬁrst observation m and n are both even, in which case a m 2 = a n 2 , or m and n are both odd, in which case am−1 = an−1. Thus in both cases we get a contradiction to the fact that m + n is minimal. Comment: We see the initial observation that for n ≥ 1, an > 1 if n is even, and an < 1 if n is odd, pretty much solved the problem. Playing around with the ﬁrst few terms in the sequence is always a good idea, especially if they are reasonably nice small numbers. Induction is another thing to keep in mind when faced with these types of problems (although its application is often more tricky than in this problem.) Problems on sequences come in all kinds of shapes and sizes. Solving these problems usually involves noticing some non-trivial facts about the sequence and then combining them to prove the desired property. Here are a few things you should consider when doing a problem on sequences: • Prove the sequence is increasing/decreasing/non-increasing/non-decreasing. • Prove the elements in the sequence are pairwise distinct. • Show the terms in the inﬁnite sequence take on ﬁnitely many values. Then you can ﬁnd two terms in the sequence that are equal to each other. • If you have a non-decreasing sequence of integers that is bounded, then it is eventually constant. • Prove that the sequence is periodic. 2 Winter Camp 2012 Sequences Alexander Remorov • (Usually does not work for non-trivial problems, but still worth a try) Write down the ﬁrst few terms in the sequence and try to see some kind of pattern. Then maybe use induction to prove this pattern holds. • Often you are required to prove a certain property about the nth term in the sequence. Using induction on n may do the trick. • Often a sequence is deﬁned recursively using a certain expression. It is often useful to play around with this expression and possibly rewrite it in another form. • Construct a new sequence from the given one. • Consider some term in the sequence satisfying a speciﬁc property. • (If it is possible) Look at the largest or smallest element in the sequence - especially useful if you are trying to show the sequence is constant. The problems below are approximately arranged in increasing order of diﬃculty. For sequence problems, where solutions are often short but somewhat ”random”, diﬀerent people may have very diﬀerent opinions about how diﬃcult a particular problem is. So I cannot guarantee that you will ﬁnd, say, problem 5, easier than problem 20. Hints are available at the end of the handout. Look at them only if you have worked on a problem for over an hour and still think you are stuck. There are a lot of problems, so it is extremely unlikely that you will be able to ﬁnish them all during the session (or before the end of the camp.) I strongly recommend to still try some problems you don’t get to today on your own time later this year. The best way to get good at solving sequence problems (considering that heavy machinery is rarely used) is to just do a lot of practice. Enjoy! 1 Problems 1. A sequence of real numbers a0, a1, . . . is deﬁned as follows. a0 is an arbitrary real number and for n ≥ 0, an+1 = ⌊an⌋{an}. (Here, ⌊x⌋ denotes the greatest integer less than or equal to x, and {x} = x − ⌊x⌋). Prove that an = an+2 for n suﬃciently large. 2. Let a1, a2, . . . be a sequence of integers with inﬁnitely many positive terms and inﬁnitely many negative terms. Suppose that for each positive integer n, the numbers a1, a2, . . . , an leave n diﬀerent remainders when divided by n. Prove that each integer occurs exactly once in the sequence. 3. The sequences {an}∞ n=1 and {bn}∞ n=1 are deﬁned as follows. a1 = 1, b1 = 2, and for n ≥ 1: an+1 = 1 + an + anbn bn , bn+1 = 1 + bn + anbn an Prove that a2008 < 5. 4. A sequence {xn}∞ n=0 is deﬁned as follows. x0 = a, x1 = 2 and xn = 2xn−1xn−2 − xn−1 − xn−2 + 1 for n ≥ 2 Find all integers a such that 2x3n − 1 is a perfect square for all n ≥ 1. 3 Winter Camp 2012 Sequences Alexander Remorov 5. Let k be a positive integer greater than or equal to 3. The sequence {an}∞ n=k satisﬁes ak = 2k and for n > k: an = { an−1 + 1 if gcd(an−1, n) = 1 2n if gcd(an−1, n) > 1 Prove that the sequence {an − an−1}∞ n=k+1 contains inﬁnitely many primes. 6. Determine if there exist positive integers a, b such that all terms in the sequence {xn}∞ n=1 deﬁned by: x1 = 2010, x2 = 2011 xn+2 = xn + xn+1 + a √xnxn+1 + b are integers. 7. Assume sequences of real numbers a0, a1, . . . , a2n and b0, b1, . . . , b2n satisfy the following con- ditions: (a) For i = 0, 1, . . . , 2n − 1, have ai + ai+1 ≥ 0; (b) For j = 0, 1, . . . , n − 1, have a2j+1 ≤ 0; (c) For any integers p, q with 0 ≤ p ≤ q ≤ n, have ∑2q k=2p bk ≥ 0. Prove that ∑2n i=0(−1)iaibi ≥ 0 and determine when equality holds. 8. A sequence of positive integers {an}∞ n=1 is constructed as follows. a1 is an arbitrary positive integer greater than or equal to 2, and for n ≥ 2, an is the smallest positive integer that is not coprime with an−1 and not equal to a1, a2, . . . , an−1. Prove that {an}∞ n=1 contains every positive integer except 1. 9. A sequence of real numbers a1, a2, . . . , an is given. For each i, 1 ≤ i ≤ n, deﬁne: di = max{ai|1 ≤ j ≤ i} − min{ai|i ≤ j ≤ n} and let d = max{di|1 ≤ i ≤ n}. (a) Prove that for any real numbers x1 ≤ x2 ≤ . . . ≤ xn, max{|xi − ai||1 ≤ i ≤ n} ≥ d 2 (6) (b) Show that there are real numbers x1 ≤ x2 ≤ . . . ≤ xn such that equality holds in (6). 10. Let p be a prime number greater than 3. Show that there exist integers a1, a2, . . . , ak such that − p 2 < a1 < a2 < . . . < ak < p 2 and: p − a1 |a1| · p − a2 |a2| · · · p − ak |ak| is a power of 3. 11. A sequence of positive integers {an}∞ n=1 is deﬁned as follows. a1 is an arbitrary positive integer, and for n ≥ 1, an+1 = an 5 if an is divisible by 5, and an+1 = ⌊an√5⌋ if an is not divisible by 5. Prove that eventually the sequence is strictly increasing. 12. Find all positive integers n greater than 2 for which there exist n positive integers a1, a2, . . . , an, not all equal, such that a1a2, a2a3, . . . , ana1 is an arithmetic progression (in this order) with non-zero common diﬀerence. 4 Winter Camp 2012 Sequences Alexander Remorov 13. A sequence of positive integers {an}∞ n=1 contains every positive integer at least once. For every two distinct positive integers m, n, the sequence satisﬁes: 1 1998 < an − am n − m < 1998 Prove that |an − n| < 2000000 for all positive integers n. 14. Let a1, a2, . . . , an be distinct positive integers. Prove that there exist distinct indices i, j such that ai + aj does not divide any of the numbers 3a1, 3a2, . . . , 3an. 15. Let a0, a1, a2, . . . be a sequence of positive integers such that gcd(an, an+1) > an−1 for all n ≥ 1. Prove that an ≥ 2n for all n ≥ 0. 16. Show that there exists an inﬁnite bounded sequence {an}∞ n=1 such that for every two distinct positive integers m, n, it satisﬁes: |am − an| ≥ 1 m − n (A sequence {an}∞ n=1 is bounded if there exist real numbers C1, C2 such that C1 ≤ an ≤ C2 for all positive integers n.) 17. Let x0, x1, . . . , xn0−1 be integers, and let d1, d2, . . . , dk be positive integers with n0 = d1 > d2 > . . . dk and gcd(d1, d2, . . . , dk) = 1. For every integer n ≥ n0, deﬁne xn = ⌊ xn−d1 + xn−d2 + . . . + xn−dk k ⌋ Prove that the sequence {xn}∞ n=1 is eventually constant. 18. Let n be a positive integer. Given a sequence ϵ1, . . . , ϵn−1 with ϵi = 0 or ϵi = 1 for 1 ≤ i ≤ n−1, the sequences a0, . . . , an and b0, . . . , bn are deﬁned as follows. a0 = b0 = 1, a1 = b1 = 7, and: ai+1 = { 2ai−1 + 3ai, if ϵi = 0 3ai−1 + ai, if ϵi = 1 bi+1 = { 2bi−1 + 3bi, if ϵn−i = 0 3bi−1 + bi, if ϵn−i = 1 for i = 1, 2 . . . , n − 1. Prove an = bn. 19. Let a1, a2, a3, . . . be a sequence of real numbers and s a positive integer such that: an = max{ak + an−k|1 ≤ k ≤ n − 1} for all n > s Show that there exist positive integers l ≤ s and N such that an = al + an−l for all n ≥ N . 20. Suppose there exists a sequence of positive integers a1, a2, . . . , an satisfying ak+1 = a2 k + 1 ak−1 + 1 − 1 for k = 2, . . . , n − 1. Prove that n ≤ 4. 5 Winter Camp 2012 Sequences Alexander Remorov 21. Suppose that every positive integer has been colored either red or blue. Prove that there exists an inﬁnite sequence of positive integers {an}∞ n=1 such that the integers a1, a1+a2 2 , a2, a2+a3 2 , a3, . . . all have the same color. 22. Let s1, s2, s3, . . . be an inﬁnite sequence of rational numbers, such that not all of its terms are the same. Let t1, t2, t3, . . . be another inﬁnite sequence of rational numbers, such that not all of its terms are the same. Suppose (si − sj)(ti − tj) is an integer for all i, j. Prove that there exists a rational number r, such that (si − sj)r and ti−tj r are integers for all i, j. 23. Suppose that s1, s2, s3, . . . is a strictly increasing sequence of positive integers such that the sub-sequences ss1, ss2, ss3, . . . and ss1+1, ss2+1, ss3+1, . . . are both arithmetic progressions. Prove that the sequence s1, s2, s3, . . . is itself an arithmetic progression. 24. Let A0 = (a1, . . . , an) be a ﬁnite sequence of real numbers. For every k ≥ 0, from the sequence Ak = (x1, . . . , xn) construct a new sequence Ak+1 as follows. (i) Partition {1, 2, . . . , n} into two disjoint sets I and J, such that | ∑ i∈I xi − ∑ j∈J xj| obtains the smallest possible value over all possible partitions. (We allow the sets I or J to be empty; in this case the corresponding sum is 0.) If there are several such partitions, one is chosen arbitrarily. (ii) Deﬁne Ak+1 = (y1, . . . , yn) where yi = xi + 1 if i ∈ I and yi = xi − 1 if i ∈ J. Prove that for some k, the sequence Ak contains an element x such that |x| ≥ n 2 . 2 Problem Sources Warm-up Problem 1: Finland 1980. Warm-up Problem 2: IberoAmerican MO 2009. Remaining problems: 1. Consider the sequence ⌊an⌋. 2. Try looking at the ﬁrst few terms in the sequence. 3. Think about how to combine the expressions for an+1 and bn+1 to get something simpler. 4. Construct a new sequence. 5. Play around with what the terms in the sequence may look like. 6. Multiply the expression given in the problem by something. 7. Use induction on n. 8. Play around with what the terms in the sequence may look like; consider primes. 9. Use the deﬁnition of d to get a more explicit expression for it. 10. Work modulo 3. 11. Consider two consecutive terms. 12. You can’t construct this sequence for all n. 13. Prove that if m > n and am < an then m − n < 2000000. 14. Assume wlog a1 < a2 < . . . < an. 15. Use induction on n. 16. Consider √2. 17. Prove the sequence is periodic. 18. Let w be the ”word” ϵ1ϵ2 · · · ϵn−1; ¯w be the ”word” ϵn−1ϵn−2 · · · ϵ1. Deﬁne an = (1, 7)w, bn = (1, 7) ¯w. You want to show (1, 7)w = (1, 7) ¯w using induction on n. 19. Consider ak k . 20. Rewrite the expression given in the problem. What can you say about the parity of the terms? 21. Assume you keep constructing such a sequence for as long as you can, and it is not possible to ”construct” the next term. 22. Think about how you can transform the sequences. 23.
